texts.definition: Activities that can primarily be solved through reasoning.
markups: <style="Definition">Activities that can primarily be solved through reasoning.</style>

It is not always apparent what actions one should try to perform to overcome challenges in games. This may be because players do not have all the game elements or information required, but can also be because the solutions require multiple actions performed consecutively and in an order that is not intuitive. In both cases, the activity players need to perform to find the solution is a <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style>. In some cases, the solutions may be drawing conclusions from the available information and, in others, testing hypotheses and rejecting impossible ones.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Jigsaw%20Puzzles">Jigsaw Puzzles</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tangram">Tangram</link></style> are early examples of artifacts requiring <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> and are in fact more often called puzzles and games.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cluedo">Cluedo</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mastermind">Mastermind</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ricochet%20Robots">Ricochet Robots</link></style> are examples of ordinary <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> that require extensive <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> but puzzles have also been constructed based on <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Go">Go</link></style>, and the card game <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Contract%20Bridge">Contract Bridge</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mansions%20of%20Madness">Mansions of Madness</link></style> is a board game that uses <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> as small challenges interjected into the main gameplay.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bejeweled">Bejeweled</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cogs">Cogs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minesweeper">Minesweeper</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sokoban">Sokoban</link></style> are all examples of computer-based <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Puzzle%20Games">Puzzle Games</link></style> but <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Adventure%20Games">Adventure Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Dig">The Dig</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/King's%20Quest%20series">King's Quest series</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Myst%20series">Myst series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zork%20series">Zork series</link></style> also require extensive amounts of <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style>.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

The prime challenge to require <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> is to figure out some information (e.g., facts, phrases, a sequence of actions) that players should in turn figure out, and make this not to easy or difficult to do. This means that a <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> goal is the core of <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> activities.

<style="Link"><link="solution-uncertainty">Solution Uncertainty</link></style> makes it possible to engage in <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> but there are examples of patterns that can be used to create puzzles that explicitly need to be dealt with. <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style> can easily require thinking before they are done, especially if <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="obstacles">Obstacles</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style> exist (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sokoban">Sokoban</link></style> have all of these except <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style>). Related to this is the task of achieving <style="Link"><link="alignment">Alignment</link></style> (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zoo%20Keeper">Zoo Keeper</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bejeweled%20series">Bejeweled series</link></style>), and in general can any type of <style="Link"><link="game-world-navigation">Game World Navigation</link></style> require some level of <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style>. Puzzles can also be more related to <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>, e.g. when <style="Link"><link="capture">Capture</link></style> is combined with <style="Link"><link="bidding">Bidding</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="investments">Investments</link></style> (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Poker">Poker</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Chess">Chess</link></style> are examples of the two first) but here there may not exist a perfect solution so the <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> may be to find the best solution which may be the one with the least <style="Link"><link="penalties">Penalties</link></style> involved. Other examples of <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>-oriented <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> include having to do <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> without using direct <style="Link"><link="line-sight">Line of Sight</link></style>, finding the <style="Link"><link="achilles-heels">Achilles' Heels</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> (or more generally to identify and find workarounds to <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> with <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>). Quite naturally, the opponents in <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> situations also are likely to engage in <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> to <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> attacks. Many types of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style>, diegetic or real, can be the base for <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> as well. One example of this is handling <style="Link"><link="internal-rivalry">Internal Rivalry</link></style> in groups with <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="red-herrings">Red Herrings</link></style> are ways of introducing <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> that do not need to be engaged in (i.e. they can be considered <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>) or is misleading to begin to study.

The difficulty of <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> is often related to number of events needed, number of game elements involved, and if players have access to all information needed at all time. Varying these can effectively be used to control the difficult, see for example the difference in difficulty between different <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Sokoban">Sokoban</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="time-limits">Time Limits</link></style> can be used to give players a hard deadline before which the puzzle must be solved (e.g., <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ricochet%20Robots">Ricochet Robots</link></style>, but this requires that the games are <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> (or makes them into this). <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> (perhaps in the form of <style="Link"><link="player-aids">Player Aids</link></style>) and <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style> can quite obviously make the <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> easier by giving partial answers or pointing players in the right direction for finding these. Depending on the size of the puzzle, <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> can also provide help. Besides these possibilities, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Reversibility">Reversibility</link></style> makes <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> easier since players can experiment with solutions while the presences of <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style> makes the activities more difficult. Many types of <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> can be designed to allow <style="Link"><link="trial-error-solutions">Trial and Error Solutions</link></style>, including <style="Link"><link="lucky-guess-solutions">Lucky Guess Solutions</link></style>.

Games that do not change puzzles between game sessions have problems with providing <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="further-player-improvement-potential">Further Player Improvement Potential</link></style>

(but this may not be a concrete problem if large number of <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> can instead be provided). This can often be avoided through the use of <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style>, but this requires that the <style="Link"><link="randomness">Randomness</link></style> used can guarantee that at least one solution exists. The existence of several solutions in general can add some <style="Link"><link="replayability">Replayability</link></style> to games but do so only primarily if they offer alternative developments of <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> or if they have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Perceivable%20Margins">Perceivable Margins</link></style> compared to each other.

<style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> is often the core activity in <style="Link"><link="alternate-reality-gameplay">Alternate Reality Gameplay</link></style> due to the possibility of spreading <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> over large areas and the possibility for many players to work together on solving puzzles. Even the invitations to these games, which are usually <style="Link"><link="rabbit-hole-invitations">Rabbit Hole Invitations</link></style>, require players to engage in <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> to be able to even start playing them.

<style="Link"><link="quizzes">Quizzes</link></style> do not require <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> but can be seen as an alternative that relies on memory rather than reasoning. However, guessing the answers to <style="Link"><link="quizzes">Quizzes</link></style> can be seen as a form <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style>.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

Completing <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> goals is a form of <style="Link"><link="stimulated-planning">Stimulated Planning</link></style>, as the challenge lies in finding the right combination of actions rather than performing the actions. This planning is typically a form of <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style>, and is more or less incompatible with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Limited%20Planning%20Ability">Limited Planning Abilities</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> requires <style="Link"><link="memorizing">Memorizing</link></style> if players do not have perceptual access to all the needed game elements all the time. Whatever the exact type of activity required to do the <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style>, it provides opportunity for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Cognitive%20Engrossment">Cognitive Engrossment</link></style>, and being skillful in solving puzzles is a form of <style="Link"><link="gameplay-mastery">Gameplay Mastery</link></style>. <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> encourages <style="Link"><link="experimenting">Experimenting</link></style> if contained in games that support <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Reversibility">Reversibility</link></style>.

Puzzles that can be solved through manipulation of the game environment provide <style="Link"><link="pve">PvE</link></style> gameplay and instantiate <style="Link"><link="configuration">Configuration</link></style> goals based upon <style="Link"><link="movement">Movement</link></style>. These can actually be solved by simply trying all combinations although this requires players to do repetitious actions (i.e. <style="Link"><link="excise">Excise</link></style>). This possibility can be difficult to design away; it cannot be avoided even with <style="Link"><link="irreversible-events">Irreversible Events</link></style> or depletion of <style="Link"><link="non-renewable-resources">Non-Renewable Resources</link></style> if players can perform <style="Link"><link="save-load-cycles">Save-Load Cycles</link></style> or the games are <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Quick%20Games">Quick Games</link></style>.

Gameplay based on <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> does not in itself introduce <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> or the need to act before one wants to, and this makes the pattern a suitable candidate to create <style="Link"><link="casual-gameplay">Casual Gameplay</link></style> but since game designers can have precise control over the number of events and game elements involved the pattern can also support <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="complex-gameplay">Complex Gameplay</link></style>. This also makes the pattern more common for <style="Link"><link="single-player-games">Single-Player Games</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="turn-based-games">Turn-Based Games</link></style> compared to <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="real-time-games">Real-Time Games</link></style> even if numerous exception exist. <style="Link"><link="zero-player-games">Zero-Player Games</link></style> are in many cases built around some form of <style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> in the sense that players of these games have to plan in advance what actions their agents should perform.

<style="CurrentLink">Puzzle Solving</style> combined with <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> that contain a puzzle each provide a form of <style="Link"><link="meta-games">Meta Games</link></style>. These in turn provide <style="Link"><link="negotiable-game-sessions">Negotiable Game Sessions</link></style> for the individual puzzles if they require varying amount time to complete.
